author: timbeiko
content:
I'd be OK renaming "Core" to "Execution" and adding a "Consensus" category (or even having both as sub-categories of "Core" post-merge). My dream is that we use EIPs to describe changes at a high level, but keep the technical specs in https://github.com/ethereum/execution-specs/ and https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/. I think it's a bit harder to talk about upgrades without EIPs (e.g. I wish Altair had 3 EIPs describing the 3 changes at a high level), and also think that EIPs tend to be a poor format to describe complex technical changes (as we saw with 1559). 

Then, we can just use branches on the specs: `main` == what's on mainnet right now, when we plan a new upgrade, we create a new branch (ex: `shanghai`). When an EIP is proposed for an upgrade, the author opens a PR against that branch, and when the EIP is included in the upgrade, the PR is merged. If the EIP is pushed back to the next upgrade, champions need to rebase on the "new" master.

author: samwilsn
content:
I like parts of the EIP process as it stands now, but I dislike that it doesn't maintain a "current" version of the specification. You can only assemble mainnet as a series of diffs from frontier.

---

I think, going forward, we should treat EIPs as "annotated diffs" with two parts: the descriptive portion, and the technical portion.

The descriptive portion describes the motivation, security considerations, and such, as those sections are defined currently, and would be encoded into a markdown file inside the spec repo (maybe in an `eips/frontier` -style directory.)

The technical portion would literally be a diff against the relevant spec repo, and would be encoded as the actual changes in the commit.

---

As for the actual repository/branching structure, I think it's pretty obvious that the default branch on GitHub (whether it's `main` or `master`, or whatever) should track mainnet.

It's tempting to track each hardfork as a branch, and proposed EIPs as PRs into the corresponding hardfork branch. The downside to this approach is that there's an information availability trade-off: either we merge EIP-PRs early, but lose the link between the technical portion and the descriptive portion as EIPs are edited; or we hold off on merging EIP-PRs until the EIP is final, but don't get overall picture of the hardfork's diff until _all_ the EIPs are final. I don't really have a better solution for this though.
